In older horror films, when the main characters were in trouble, they could not call for help or the police easily. But now, with mobile phones, this seems less real. To keep the story exciting, the solution is no phone signal! If you are a hero in a horror film, at the important moment when you need to call for help, you will not have any signal. Or your phone battery will die just as you try to call. Sometimes both happen.

In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America had a big problem. Their most popular banana, called Gros Michel or Big Mike, was dying. Now, the same problem is happening again with Big Mike's replacement, the Cavendish banana. Gros Michel was popular because its bananas were thick-skinned, sweet, and easy to transport. The main company growing and selling these bananas was United Fruit. They grew bananas by making copies from the stems of plants instead of using seeds, and they planted many plants very close together in their fields.

Spider venom helps spiders catch and kill their food. Most spiders don't have venom that can hurt people. Only about 25 spider species make venom that could be harmful to humans. Even if you get bitten by a spider, it's usually not very dangerous.   Australia has a famous spider, the Sydney funnel-web spider. Since they created a special medicine (anti-venom) in 1981, this spider hasn’t caused any deaths. However, it’s important to be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. If they feel threatened, they can protect themselves. They throw a cloud of tiny, prickly hairs at the person trying to hurt them. These hairs stick to the attacker’s skin or eyes.

This idea is a common pattern in horror movies from the 1990s. It begins with a group of teenagers having fun. Then, almost everyone dies, and only one girl survives. In the first scenes, the girl is usually shy, innocent, and not very strong. By the end of the movie, she has become the toughest and most clever person. In almost every story, the last girl wins.

If we want to find out where our ability to speak complex languages came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. It’s not just about how big our brains are; it’s important what else our brains can do and when they started to develop. There are very few clues about this in the past. Old tools and objects left by our ancestors don't tell us how well they could speak. However, we can see that early humans developed their mouths, throats, and tongues about 100,000 years ago. At that time, they could start making complex sounds. Before that, scientists can only guess if they were using simpler sounds to talk.

It's society, not nature, that says girls should focus on arts and humanities and leave math and physics to boys. There are also few positive female role models in science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often feature male scientists or inventors. Additionally, scientists are seen as socially awkward and their work as lonely. These false stereotypes from the media can make science seem unappealing to girls. If girls saw more women succeeding in science, they would feel more confident and belong more in those subjects.

The Scallion is a free newspaper printed every week and given out in university buildings. About 10,000 students read it. Students write and produce the newspaper. A survey shows that many students and staff like the newspaper for fun, learning about culture, and gaining work experience. Printing the newspaper costs a lot of money. Also, some students find it hard to get a copy because they must go to the university to pick one up. Another problem is that many copies are thrown away as litter on campus, which is bad for the environment.

At Girox Foods, about 12 percent of our employees leave each year. That is a bit higher than the industry average of 7 percent. This report looks at why our employees stay or leave. We will suggest ways to make the workplace better and keep more staff.

What the speaker said felt very true. I think the more connected we are, the more isolated we might feel. This isn't as big of a problem for my generation since we grew up without much technology. We know how to be alone and understand that it's okay. But young people under 20 are different. They are always communicating but rarely experience solitude. They might not learn to enjoy being alone. Also, they're learning to communicate through edited messages instead of in real conversations with people in front of them.

Do not always give negative feedback right after positive feedback. If positive and negative feedback always come together, the positive comments can lose their value and be ignored. Make sure to give positive feedback sometimes just to praise someone, without adding any criticism.
